title: Mr. Johnson's Recovery Journey Post-Lobectomy
clinical_history: Mr. James Johnson is a 64-year-old retired firefighter who underwent a right upper lobectomy 3 weeks ago due to early-stage lung cancer. Prior to the surgery, Mr. Johnson was in relatively good health, although he had a history of smoking for 20 years, having quit 15 years ago. Post-operatively, he has been experiencing difficulty with deep breathing and has noted pain upon inspiration which has limited his ability to engage in physical activities. He reports increased tiredness by mid-afternoon and is finding it hard to resume his daily routine, including his walks around the neighborhood.

nprs.affected_area: intercostal and back muscles due to compensatory mechanisms

aggrevating_factors: deep breathing, coughing, lying on the right side, and any attempt at lifting.
picture: [insert image of the thoracic region highlighting the surgical site on the right side]
easing_factors: sitting upright, using a pillow for support against the surgical site when coughing, taking prescribed pain medications
past_history: Mr. Johnson had a significant smoking history but has been smoke-free for the past 15 years. No other significant comorbidities.
medications: Oxycodone for pain management, Lisinopril for hypertension.
personal_history: Mr. Johnson is married with two adult children, enjoys fishing, and was previously active in community volunteer firefighting. He expresses a strong desire to regain his pre-surgery vitality.
imaging: Post-operative chest X-ray shows normal surgical findings with no pneumothorax or pleural effusions.
